repnme.cdata!: Uganda - El Nino Emergency Road Repair Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, with only modest
            institutional development impacts. Three main lessons are
            drawn from the project: 1) The design, and implementation
            arrangements of an emergency project should demonstrate
            realism, and should thus be simple, straight forward, with
            strong focus on addressing the urgency of the emergency.
            But, such a project should not be designed to address issues
            unrelated to the emergency situation. In this respect, the
            inclusion of the Atiak - Moyo road, could be seen as a
            distraction, for both the Government and the Bank's
            implementation teams, and should not have been included in
            an emergency project. Moreover, to stress the importance of
            institutional reforms - such as was the case of this project
            anticipating the eventual transfer of functions from the
            Ministry of Works, Housing and Communications (MOWHC) to the
            Road Agency Formation Unit (RAFU) and a future road
            authority - may also be seen as a distraction from the tasks
            of organizing, and motivating assigned staff to focus on the
            urgency of the task. 2) The case of this project suggest the
            importance of ensuring that Bank procurement guidelines -
            and how they are applied in an emergency situation - be
            tailored to the need for a speedy implementation. Even with
            fast tracking in preparation and appraisal, the response
            time proved to be too long for the client. The Bank should,
            as part of its operations reform process, examine this
            constraint, and provide particularly, simplified procurement
            guidelines and procedures to be followed for eligible
            expenditures in emergency operations. 3) Appropriate
            institutional arrangements are key to successfully handling
            emergency situations. Most countries prone to natural
            disasters, do not have institutional arrangements in place
            to make a rapid response when disaster hits. However in the
            case of this particular project, some interesting
            developments did take place in terms of policy, and
            emergency institutional arrangements, e.g. on preventive
            bridge maintenance. The Bank should, as a general rule,
            identify the risks of disaster prone, developing countries,
            and help governments institutionalize arrangements, to
            manage recurrent disasters.

repnme.cdata!: Uganda - El Nino Emergency Road Repair Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The El Nino Emergency Road Repair
            Project aims at providing emergency recovery assistance to
            the Government of Uganda for the restoration/rehabilitation
            of key road and bridge facilities severely damaged by the
            flooding, associated with the El Nino weather pattern. The
            project will contribute to : i) decreasing
            infrastructure-related market and distribution costs
            countrywide; ii) securing the timely delivery of social
            services to the affected population; iii) facilitating the
            productive settlement of war refugees in Northern Uganda;
            and iv) stabilizing the eco-system near the affected roads.
            The project consists of four components. First, repair of
            damaged road sections will support repairs and replacement
            of pipe culverts on 96 identified sections of road
            countrywide. Second, rehabilitation and regravelling of
            Atiak-Moyo Road will comprise rehabilitation/regravelling of
            90 kilometers of gravel road as well as repairs of five
            bridges and two ferry landings. The third component will
            repair or replace box culverts and about 120 bridges. The
            fourth component is the procurement of pipe culverts and
            Bailey Bridge sections. Finally, the fifth component will
            finance consultant services for engineering studies and
            civil work supervision.
